complaint_summary: Budhoo filed a suit for pre-emption claiming superior rights as co-owner in the village, seeking ownership of land purchased by Pir Bakhsh.
investigation_summary: Budhoo relied on Jamabandi of 1966-67 and Mutation No. 22 to prove ownership. Pir Bakhsh presented Mutation No. 279 and Jamabandi Exh. D. 1 but failed to prove ownership under section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed both Civil Revision No. 178 of 1972 and Civil Revision No. 2 of 1973, ruling that oral sales and unregistered documents do not confer ownership rights under section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act. The respondent was deemed owner by adverse possession.
Decision_or_verdict: Petitions dismissed; parties to bear their own costs.
legal_arguments: Section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act prohibits oral sales from conferring ownership rights.
Adverse possession after 12 years grants ownership rights.
No distinction between pre-emptor and vendee regarding ownership rights.
assets: 196 kanals of land in Bismillahpur, Tehsil and District Rahim Yar Khan
key_issues: Validity of oral sales under section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act
Adverse possession as a basis for ownership

maxims.Adverse Possession: Ownership can be claimed after continuous possession for a prescriptive period.

legal_terms.Pre-emption: The right of a co-owner to purchase property before it is sold to another party.
legal_terms.Adverse Possession: Acquiring ownership through continuous possession over a statutory period.

words_and_phrases.Jamabandi: Land revenue record showing ownership details.
words_and_phrases.Mutation: Record of transfer of ownership in land.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around pre-emption rights and the applicability of section 54 of the Transfer of Property Act. Oral sales and unregistered documents were deemed insufficient to confer ownership rights. The respondent's ownership was upheld based on adverse possession.
